If the transformation \\( T(s) \\) is applied at t = 0, resulting in \\( R(T(s)) = R(e^{st}) \\), and then the response function is evaluated over time without further intervention, will the characteristics of \\( R(e^{st}) \\) at any time t be fundamentally different from \\( R(z) \\) at z = 1?
Explanation: Applying \\( T(s) \\) alters the input to the response function, shifting it from z = 1 to z = e^{st}, a trajectory dependent on the value of s. Since the transformation changes the point at which R is evaluated, the behaviors and attributes (poles and zeros) of \\( R(e^{st}) \\) can differ significantly from \\( R(z) \\) at z = 1 due to the exponential nature of the transformation.
